montalban

The best flicks I've ever seen are
 
 Bliss (1985), starring Barry Otto
 Being There (1979), starring Peter Sellers
 Exclaibur (1981), starring Helen Mirren
 Zardoz (1974), starring Sean Connery
 
 
 None of these films would ever be on a critic's choice of best made film. And in fact I've not met anyone who likes any of these, because some are a wee bit tasteless.
 
 However, they intrigue me as they are stories of flawed human beings meeting unusual challenges.
gilligan8503

in no particular order:
 
 pulp fiction (everything), goodfellas (true story), a clockwork orange (everything), clerks (best college project ever), fight club (edward norton), full metal jacket (r. lee ernie), mallrats (jason lee is hilarious), memento (backwards is good), dr. strangelove (peter sellers is great!), office space (case of the mondays), requiem for a dream (darren aronnofsky), pi (darren aronnofsky), american history x (edward norton is god), the breakfast club (brat pack), stand by me (great 'childhood' movie), apocalypse now (the horror, the horror...), braveheart (freedom!), fellowship of the ring, the two towers, dumb and dumber, chasing amy, blue velvet, 2001: a space odyssey (art film/intellectual film), wet hot american summer (hilarious), american beauty (just great), happiness (philip seymore hoffman), matrix (only the first), training day (best gang movie to date), reservoir dogs (ear), jackie brown (the man samuel), true love (drugs, money, and killing), crash (****ed up movie... don't watch with your mother), amedeus (words can't describe), eraserhead (art movie), lost highway (this movie scared the XXXX out of me), the shining (classic), barry lyndon, jay and silent bob strike back (snoochie booches), the green mile (mouse resort), bowling for columbine (micheal moore movie), roger and me (ditto), dogma (what can i say? buddy christ), finding nemo (the last good movie in awhile), monty python: the meaning of life (no need to explain), monty python: holy grail (ditto), and more i'm sure.
 
 if i had to choose, pulp fiction and a clockwork orange overall.
witzelcheck

You know, Gilligan, I'm really going to have to agree with you there. I've seen most of those, and the ones I have seen, I've loved; some of them I own.
 I'm going to have to add Office Space  to that. 
 "O Brother, where art thou?" is really good too. Homer's Oddesy to entertain today's audience. Done really well. 
 If you're into chick flicks, "10 things I hate about you" is a really funny movie based off of Shakspeare's Taming of the shrew, of more specifically, Kiss me Kate. (Julia Stiles and Heath Ledger - spelling?)
 But yeah...
 Fight Club, Memento, (both are really messed up) American Beauty, LOTR, Monty Python (can never get enough of that) and others listed above. 
 Oh, and if you have no life ( NOT a bad thing) the Mystery Science Theatre ones are GREAT. Yes, I would know.
Jimbo

everything looks pretty good so far.
 I'm gonna go with the above and add Army of Darkness, They Live, A Guy Thing, Hackers, Fight Club cannot be mentioned enough, Little Nicky, Gone in 60 Seconds, Van Wilder, that's about all I got right now
sundowner

I loved "O Brother", what a great movie. I must agree with Gilligan on many of his choices, especially the Kubrick movies. I would add:
 Airplane (ever seen a grown man naked?), Bringing out the Dead, The Hunt for Red October, The Hannible Lector Trilogy, Die Hard 1 and 3 (2 was really lame!), Flatliners (a total must see), Sommersby (my all time favorite), Saving Private Ryan, Tombstone, Meet the Parents, American Pie Movies (one of my friends reminds me of a real live Stiffler), Weird Science, A Walk in the Clouds, Fortress (has anyone seen this one? There are 2 of them, the one I am thinking of is based in the Australian outback where a class of school children are kidnapped), Romancing the Stone, Trading Places, 8 Seconds, PCU (great comedy), Gettysburg, Heartbreak Ridge, Jaws, Spaceballs (Sir, the radar, it's been jammed), Blazing Saddles (swing lo...sweet chariot?), Bull Durham, Major League, Platoon, Friday, Top Gun, A Christmas Story, The Big Lebowski, and last but not least, Animal House.
 
 Movies I could have done without: Titanic (hell, it could have been worse, it could have been snowing), Forrest Gump (nuff said), The Doors, Sleepless in Seattle (watch the movie, good sedative), any movie with Adam Sandler (I think I missed this part of my generation), and just about every movie billed as the "greatest romantic comedy of the year".

I am a total Sci-fi and Fantasy buff, so I think you guys are dumb.
 
 Lord of the Rings series (Best Epic ever. Gandalf is my hero)
 Matrix series (There is no spoon)
 The Mummy (Who would have guessed that Brendan Fraser would have an acting career after encino man)
 The Mummy returns (Imotep.)
 Harry Potter II (Had a lot more depth than the first)
 Stargate (This was one of the most professionally filmed and scripted movies I have ever seen)
 Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom (You call him Dr. Jones)
 Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade (We named the dog Indiana)
 20,000 Leagues Under the Sea (James Mason is God)
 Devil's Advocate (If you can look past Keanu's acting, the concept is fresh)
 The Replacements (I Will Survive....)
 Fifth Element (I am Corbin Dallas)
 Pluto Nash (I heard that toaster crack)
 Priates of the Carribean (That has to be the best pirate I've ever seen)
 Hook (That has to be the second best pirate I've ever seen)
 Labrynth (Uhhh... Hoggle!)
 My Cousin Vinney (There goes the Quintescential Norton)
 The Whole Nine Yards (*Bangs head on steering wheel*)
 The Mask (Cameron Diaz is still a severe hottie)
 The Saint (Val Kilmer)
 Goonies (Where onto you One Eyed Willy...)
 Under Siege (Tommy Lee Jones AND Gary Busey)
 The Shining (Redrum...)
 Big Daddy (It's all about Scuba Steve)
 Monty Python's Holy Grail (Come back, I'll bite your ankles off!)
 Anything by Mel Brooks. (spaceballs, men in tights, princess bride, Dead and loving it)
 ...and yea... Dogma. (It's got Alan Rickman!!!)
